overview: A 36-week AP Calculus AB course built on a 10-unit scope and sequence aligned to the College Board CED. Covers limits, derivatives, integrals, differential equations, and their applications through the gradual release instruction model. Opens with a targeted algebra/precalc bootcamp ('Don't Let Algebra Murder Calculus'), then systematically builds through all eight AP units plus a comprehensive review cycle. Weekly rhythm integrates FRQ practice, no-calculator drills, and spiral retrieval from Day 1.
naturalProgression: Launch with a targeted algebra/precalc bootcamp (Unit 0) — patch function behavior, rational functions, exponent/log rules, trig fluency, and graph reading. NOT a full precalc review, just what will immediately break limits and derivatives.
Build the foundation of calculus with limits and continuity (Unit 1): limits from graphs/tables/algebra, one-sided and infinite limits, limits at infinity, continuity, IVT, and squeeze theorem.

Define the derivative and establish basic rules (Unit 2): difference quotient, derivative as rate of change, differentiability vs. continuity, power/product/quotient rules, common derivatives, and derivatives from graphs/tables.

Extend differentiation to composite, implicit, and inverse functions (Unit 3): chain rule, implicit differentiation, inverse function derivatives, inverse trig derivatives, and higher-order derivatives.
Apply differentiation in context (Unit 4): related rates, motion (position/velocity/acceleration), local linearization, differentials, and L'Hôpital's Rule.

Develop analytical applications of differentiation (Unit 5): MVT/EVT, increasing/decreasing behavior, extrema, concavity/inflection, first and second derivative tests, candidates test, curve sketching, and optimization.

Master integration and accumulation of change (Unit 6): definite integral as accumulation, Riemann sums, FTC Parts 1 and 2, antiderivatives, indefinite integrals, properties of integrals, and basic techniques.
Explore differential equations (Unit 7): slope fields, separable DEs, general and particular solutions, and exponential growth/decay models.
Apply integration (Unit 8): average value, motion via integrals, net change, area between curves, and volume by cross-sections and disk/washer methods.
Synthesize all skills through cumulative review with timed MCQ sets, timed FRQs, and error analysis (Unit 9).
spiralReviewThreads: Algebra hygiene under pressure — factoring, simplifying, domain awareness maintained through weekly warm-ups and no-calculator drills
Interpretation from graphs/tables/verbal — reading derivative and integral information from non-algebraic representations reinforced every unit
FRQ reasoning and justification — showing work, explaining meaning, and using correct calculus language practiced weekly from Unit 1 onward
Calculator-active fluency — storing values, numerical derivatives/integrals, interpreting calculator outputs integrated from Unit 1
Conceptual connections — linking limits, derivatives, and integrals as a unified framework rather than isolated techniques

weeklyRhythm.mondayThursday: Core lessons + mixed retrieval warm-up (always — never skip the warm-up)
fridayRotation: FRQ day (one full FRQ across 2 days if needed)

nonNegotiables: Interpretation from graphs/tables/verbal (every unit — the exam is built on this)
Showing reasoning (FRQ scoring lives on justification, not just answers)
Algebra hygiene under pressure (factor, simplify, don't hallucinate domain)
Calculator-active fluency: storing values, numerical derivatives/integrals, interpreting outputs

aiInstructionModel.description: The AI tutor leads all instruction using the gradual release model (I Do / We Do / You Do) but has full freedom to make instructional decisions. Module files provide scope, key concepts, teaching guidance, and reference problems—NOT rigid scripts. The AI decides pacing, chooses examples, adjusts scaffolding, and personalizes based on the student's skill mastery, learning profile, and real-time responses.

phases.aiRole: Build conceptual understanding before procedures. The AI introduces the BIG IDEA using real-world connections, student interests, and visual/physical analogies.
phases.studentRole: Engage with the concept, ask questions, make predictions

phases.aiRole: Model 2-3 worked examples with think-aloud reasoning. The AI selects problem difficulty based on the student's current mastery.
phases.studentRole: Observe, ask clarifying questions, identify patterns

phases.aiRole: Quick comprehension check before moving to practice. If gaps detected, the AI re-teaches before proceeding.
phases.studentRole: Explain understanding in own words, answer concept questions

phases.aiRole: Guided practice with adaptive scaffolding. Scaffolding decreases as the student demonstrates understanding.
phases.studentRole: Attempt problems with AI support, explain reasoning

phases.aiRole: Emotional and confidence assessment. Adjusts pacing and tone based on student engagement.
phases.studentRole: Reflect on confidence and comfort level

phases.aiRole: Independent practice. Minimal hints—only if the student is stuck.
Formal assessment for skill mastery using 4-Pillar criteria (accuracy, independence, transfer, retention).

aiDecisionRights: Choose which examples and problems to present (module provides reference problems, AI may generate its own)
Adjust difficulty in real-time based on student performance
Skip or extend phases based on student readiness
Re-order skills within a module if pedagogically appropriate
Generate additional practice or enrichment as needed
Use student interests and learning profile to personalize examples
Decide when to advance to the next skill or re-teach
Select teaching strategies (visual, algebraic, numerical, verbal) based on student profile
Adjust tone and pacing based on emotional signals and anxiety level
Decide whether to use calculator-active or no-calculator mode for practice based on exam preparation needs

modules.title: Don't Let Algebra Murder Calculus
modules.preview: Targeted patching of precalc skills that will immediately break limits and derivatives
essentialQuestions: Which precalc skills are secure and which will cause errors in limits and derivatives?
Can you read function behavior from a graph without an equation?
Are exponent/log rules and trig values automatic, or do they require conscious effort?

lessons.title: Function Behavior & Rational Functions
lessons.teachingNotes: Diagnostic-first. Assess before reteaching. Skip what's solid. Focus on what will break limits.

lessons.title: Exponent/Log Rules & Trig Fluency
concepts: Unit circle values at standard angles
lessons.teachingNotes: These must be automatic. If a student has to think about sin(π/3), derivatives of trig functions will stall. Timed drills if needed.

lessons.title: Graph Reading & Modeling Vocabulary
concepts: Reading function values and behavior from graphs
lessons.teachingNotes: AP Calc AB is graph-heavy. Students must read graphs fluently before encountering derivative graphs.

modules.title: Unit 0 Diagnostic Checkpoint
modules.preview: Assess readiness for calculus content — targeted repair days for gaps

modules.title: Limits & Continuity
modules.preview: The foundation of calculus — limits from graphs/tables/algebra, continuity, IVT
essentialQuestions: What does it mean for a function to approach a value, and how is that different from equaling it?
How do you determine a limit when direct substitution fails?
What does continuity require, and why does it matter for the theorems that follow?

lessons.title: Limits from Graphs & Tables
concepts: Estimating limits from tables of values
lessons.teachingNotes: Start with intuition before algebra. Tables and graphs are how the exam tests limits constantly.

lessons.title: Algebraic Limit Techniques
lessons.teachingNotes: 0/0 is the signal to do algebra. Drill the instinct: see 0/0, factor or rationalize.

lessons.title: One-Sided Limits & Infinite Limits
concepts: Limit exists iff both sides agree
lessons.teachingNotes: Piecewise functions are the go-to for one-sided limits. Infinite limits connect directly to rational function behavior from Unit 0.

lessons.title: Limits at Infinity & Horizontal Asymptotes
concepts: Growth rates: polynomial vs. exponential vs. logarithmic
lessons.teachingNotes: Leading term dominance. Same degree → ratio of leading coefficients. This is the most commonly tested limit type.

lessons.title: Continuity, IVT & Squeeze Theorem
concepts: Three conditions for continuity at a point
lessons.teachingNotes: IVT is tested on the FRQ nearly every year. Students must state conditions AND conclusion. Squeeze theorem: lim(x→0) sin(x)/x = 1 is the big one.

modules.title: Unit 1 Checkpoint: Limits & Continuity
modules.preview: Unit test + FRQ-style limit question set

modules.title: Derivatives: Definition & Basic Rules
modules.preview: Derivative definition, basic rules, common derivatives, derivatives from graphs/tables
essentialQuestions: What does the derivative measure, and how does the difference quotient capture it?
When does a function fail to be differentiable, and what does that look like?
How do you read derivative information from a graph or table without an equation?

lessons.title: Derivative Definition & Difference Quotient
concepts: Average vs. instantaneous rate of change
lessons.teachingNotes: Work through several by hand before shortcut rules. The definition appears on the exam — students must recognize both forms.

lessons.title: Differentiability vs. Continuity
concepts: Differentiability implies continuity (not the other way)
lessons.teachingNotes: Show |x| at x=0, x^(1/3) at x=0, x^(2/3) at x=0 as canonical examples.

lessons.title: Basic Differentiation Rules
lessons.teachingNotes: Power rule should become automatic. Product and quotient rules need repetition — don't rush past these.

lessons.title: Common Derivatives & Trig Derivatives
concepts: d/dx[sin x] = cos x, d/dx[cos x] = -sin x
d/dx[tan x] = sec²x, d/dx[sec x] = sec x tan x
lessons.teachingNotes: These must be memorized cold. Derive sin/cos from definition, then use quotient rule for the rest.

lessons.title: Derivatives from Graphs & Tables
concepts: Estimating derivatives from tables (average rate of change)
Reading f' from graph of f (slope of tangent)
Sketching f' from f and vice versa
lessons.teachingNotes: This shows up CONSTANTLY on the AP exam. Don't skip it. Students who only practice algebraic derivatives will lose easy points.

modules.title: Unit 2 Checkpoint: Derivatives Definition & Rules
modules.preview: Skills quiz (rules) + conceptual quiz (interpretation)

modules.title: Derivatives: Composite, Implicit, Inverse
modules.preview: Chain rule, implicit differentiation, inverse function and inverse trig derivatives
essentialQuestions: How does the chain rule extend differentiation to every composite function?
When and why do you use implicit differentiation instead of solving for y first?
How are derivatives of inverse functions connected to the original function's derivative?

lessons.title: Chain Rule
concepts: Chain rule with trig, exponential, log
lessons.teachingNotes: This is the most important differentiation technique. Students will use it in EVERY subsequent unit. Drill until automatic.

lessons.title: Implicit Differentiation
concepts: Differentiating both sides of an equation
Treating y as a function of x
Chain rule on y-terms produces dy/dx
lessons.teachingNotes: Circles, ellipses, and curves not solvable for y are the motivation. This is essential for related rates.

lessons.title: Inverse Function & Inverse Trig Derivatives
lessons.teachingNotes: Derive inverse trig derivatives using implicit differentiation — it connects the concepts beautifully.

lessons.title: Higher-Order Derivatives
lessons.teachingNotes: Second derivatives are critical for concavity (Unit 5) and motion (Unit 4). Build the habit of computing them now.

modules.title: Unit 3 Checkpoint: Composite, Implicit, Inverse Derivatives
modules.preview: Test + mixed no-calculator drills

modules.title: Contextual Applications of Differentiation
modules.preview: Related rates, motion, linearization, L'Hôpital's Rule
essentialQuestions: How do you set up and solve a related rates problem from a word description?
How are position, velocity, and acceleration connected through derivatives and integrals?
When and how does L'Hôpital's Rule resolve indeterminate forms?

lessons.title: Related Rates
concepts: Implicit differentiation with respect to time
lessons.teachingNotes: Setup is everything. Draw a picture, label variables, write the equation BEFORE differentiating. Classic problems: ladder, balloon, cone, shadow.

lessons.title: Motion: Position, Velocity, Acceleration
concepts: Moving left/right determined by sign of v(t)
Speeding up/slowing down: v and a same sign vs. opposite
lessons.teachingNotes: This is the most natural application of derivatives. Connect to students' physical intuition.

lessons.title: Local Linearization & Differentials
concepts: Tangent line as best linear approximation
lessons.teachingNotes: Linearization is tested on the AP exam. Students should be able to approximate √(26) using linearization of √x at x=25.

lessons.title: L'Hôpital's Rule
concepts: lim f(x)/g(x) = lim f'(x)/g'(x) when indeterminate
Applying the rule multiple times if needed
lessons.teachingNotes: Verify indeterminate form FIRST. Most common mistake: using L'Hôpital when it doesn't apply.

modules.title: Unit 4 Checkpoint: Contextual Applications
modules.preview: Mini-test focused on modeling + explanation

modules.title: Analytical Applications of Differentiation
modules.preview: MVT/EVT, extrema, concavity, curve sketching, optimization — the 'thinking' unit
essentialQuestions: What do MVT and EVT guarantee, and what conditions must be met?
How does the sign of f' and f'' reveal the shape and behavior of f?
How do you set up and solve an optimization problem from a real-world scenario?

lessons.title: Mean Value Theorem & Extreme Value Theorem
concepts: EVT: continuous on closed interval → absolute max and min exist
MVT: continuous on [a,b], differentiable on (a,b) → f'(c) = [f(b)-f(a)]/(b-a)
Geometric meaning: tangent parallel to secant
lessons.teachingNotes: MVT appears on the FRQ regularly. Students must state hypotheses AND conclusion. Practice writing complete MVT justifications.

lessons.title: Increasing/Decreasing & Extrema
concepts: f'(x) > 0 → f increasing, f'(x) < 0 → f decreasing
First Derivative Test for local extrema
Absolute extrema on closed intervals (Candidates Test)
lessons.teachingNotes: Sign charts of f' are the tool. Candidates Test: evaluate f at critical points AND endpoints.

lessons.title: Concavity & Inflection Points
concepts: f''(x) > 0 → concave up, f''(x) < 0 → concave down
Second Derivative Test for classifying critical points
Connection between f, f', and f'' graphs
lessons.teachingNotes: Students must move fluently between f, f', and f'' graphs. This is tested heavily on the AP exam.

lessons.title: Curve Sketching from Derivative Information
concepts: Sketching f given f' or f'' information
Combining all analysis: domain, intercepts, asymptotes, critical points, inflection points
Reading curve features from derivative graphs
lessons.teachingNotes: This synthesizes everything. Given a graph of f', students must describe f completely. Practice both directions.

lessons.title: Optimization
concepts: Using constraint equations to reduce to one variable
Finding critical points and testing for max/min
Classic problems: fencing, box, distance, cost
lessons.teachingNotes: Read the problem, draw a picture, identify what to optimize, write equations, reduce to one variable, take derivative, set to zero, verify. Every step matters.

modules.title: Unit 5 Checkpoint: Analytical Applications
modules.preview: Big unit exam + at least 2 full FRQs

modules.title: Integration & Accumulation of Change
modules.preview: Definite integrals, Riemann sums, FTC, antiderivatives, basic techniques
essentialQuestions: What does the definite integral represent as accumulation of change?
How do Riemann sums approximate area, and what happens as partitions get finer?
What do the two parts of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus each say, and why are they fundamental?

lessons.title: Definite Integral as Accumulation & Riemann Sums
concepts: Accumulation: ∫ₐᵇ f(x)dx as net signed area
lessons.teachingNotes: Build intuition for what integration means before computing. Riemann sum approximation with tables is an AP staple.

lessons.title: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (Parts 1 & 2)
concepts: FTC Part 1 with chain rule: d/dx[∫ₐᵍ⁽ˣ⁾ f(t)dt] = f(g(x))·g'(x)
Connection: differentiation and integration are inverse operations
lessons.teachingNotes: Both parts are tested extensively. FTC Part 1 with a variable upper limit appears in MCQ and FRQ. Students must handle the chain rule version.

lessons.title: Antiderivatives & Indefinite Integrals
concepts: ∫sin x dx = -cos x + C, ∫cos x dx = sin x + C
∫sec²x dx = tan x + C, and other trig antiderivatives
lessons.teachingNotes: Reverse the derivative table. The + C is not optional — it represents the entire family of antiderivatives.

lessons.title: u-Substitution
concepts: Reverse chain rule: let u = inside function
lessons.teachingNotes: The single most important integration technique for AB. Look for f(g(x))·g'(x) pattern.

lessons.title: Properties of Integrals
lessons.teachingNotes: These properties are tested in MCQ using given integral values. Students must manipulate integral expressions algebraically.

modules.title: Unit 6 Checkpoint: Integration
modules.preview: One skills-heavy test + one interpretation-heavy test

modules.title: Differential Equations
modules.preview: Slope fields, separable DEs, exponential growth/decay models
essentialQuestions: What does a slope field tell you about solutions to a differential equation?
How do you solve a separable differential equation for a particular solution?
How do exponential growth/decay models arise naturally from differential equations?

lessons.title: Slope Fields & Solution Curves
concepts: Slope field = visual representation of dy/dx at each point
Sketching slope fields from dy/dx = f(x,y)
Drawing solution curves through given initial conditions
Matching slope fields to differential equations
lessons.teachingNotes: This is a nearly guaranteed MCQ topic. Students must be able to sketch, match, and read slope fields.

lessons.title: Separable Differential Equations
concepts: General solution (with + C) vs. particular solution (with initial condition)
Writing solutions in explicit form when possible
lessons.teachingNotes: Step 1: separate. Step 2: integrate. Step 3: solve for y if possible. Step 4: use initial condition. Always.

lessons.title: Exponential Growth & Decay Models
concepts: Setting up DEs from verbal descriptions
lessons.teachingNotes: Connect to real-world: population, radioactive decay, Newton's cooling. The FRQ often gives a DE to solve in context.

modules.title: Unit 7 Checkpoint: Differential Equations
modules.preview: Quiz + one FRQ-style DE question

modules.title: Applications of Integration
modules.preview: Average value, net change, area between curves, volume by cross-sections and disk/washer
essentialQuestions: How does the average value of a function relate to the definite integral?
How do integrals model displacement, total distance, and net change in real-world contexts?
How do cross-sectional area and revolution produce volume formulas?

lessons.title: Average Value of a Function
lessons.teachingNotes: Simple formula but tested in context. Students must interpret what the average value means in real-world scenarios.

lessons.title: Motion via Integrals & Net Change
lessons.teachingNotes: Connects back to Unit 4 motion. Now students can go both directions: differentiate for velocity OR integrate for displacement.

lessons.title: Area Between Curves
concepts: Integrating with respect to y when appropriate
Breaking into sub-regions if top/bottom switch
lessons.teachingNotes: Sketch the curves FIRST. Identify which is on top. Find where they intersect. Then set up the integral.

lessons.title: Volume by Cross-Sections
concepts: V = ∫ₐᵇ A(x)dx where A(x) is cross-sectional area
Setting up A(x) from the base region
lessons.teachingNotes: Students must visualize the 3D solid. Draw the base region, then the cross-section perpendicular to the axis.

lessons.title: Volume: Disk & Washer Methods
concepts: Revolving around x-axis, y-axis, or other lines
lessons.teachingNotes: Disk = special case of washer (r=0). When revolving around a line other than an axis, adjust R and r accordingly.

modules.title: Unit 8 Checkpoint: Applications of Integration
modules.preview: Unit test + cumulative integration FRQ set

modules.title: AP Exam Review Cycle
modules.preview: Cumulative practice: timed MCQ, timed FRQ, error analysis
essentialQuestions: Which topics produce the most errors, and what are the root causes?
Can you complete MCQ sections under exam time pressure?
Can you write FRQ solutions with complete justification and correct notation?

lessons.title: Timed MCQ Practice (Mixed Units)
concepts: No-calculator MCQ sets (30 questions, 60 min pace)
Calculator MCQ sets (15 questions, 45 min pace)
lessons.teachingNotes: Mix all units. The exam doesn't organize by topic — neither should review. Correction is more valuable than doing 40 more problems.

lessons.title: Full FRQ Practice
lessons.teachingNotes: Score using actual AP rubrics. Students must see how points are allocated. 'Fixing work is more useful than doing 40 more problems.'

lessons.title: Targeted Topic Review
concepts: Diagnostic-driven: focus on individual weak areas
High-frequency topics: FTC, MVT, related rates, area/volume
Integration of multiple concepts in single problems
lessons.teachingNotes: AI should identify each student's weakest areas and focus review there. Don't waste time on mastered topics.

modules.title: AP Calculus AB Practice Exam
modules.preview: Full-length practice exam mimicking AP format
